Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk evolution-data-server
exit 0

exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: evolution-data-server bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: The evolution-data-server packages provide a unified backend for applications which interact with contacts, tasks and calendar information. Evolution Data Server was originally developed as a backend for the Evolution information management application, but is now used by various other applications. This update fixes the following bugs: Because of incorrect code segments in the Evolution Data Server, a failed IMAP message download generated a redundant error message and did not trigger another download of the IMAP message. This update fixes the erroneous code. Now, when an IMAP message fails to download, the Evolution client attempts to download the message again as intended. (BZ#1084088) The Evolution client mistakenly removed the cache of the IMAP subfolder when the "scanning for changed messages" process failed, for instance when the user cancelled this process. As a consequence, Evolution in some cases had to download summary information for all the messages in the mail folder, including the ones with information previously already downloaded, which was consuming excessive time and resources. With this update, a fix has been implemented for Evolution to handle scan interruptions properly. As a result, Evolution no longer removes the IMAP subfolder cache and thus does not have to download redundant message information. (BZ#1084973) Due to errors in the underlying code, memory leaks could occur in Evolution Data Server. This update amends these errors and the memory leaks now no longer occur. (BZ#1090816) A bug prevented Evolution Data Server from correctly processing shared mail folders on a Cyrus IMAP server. As a consequence, when it accessed a shared message folder on a Cyrus IMAP server, Evolution could not display the messages the folder contained. This bug has been fixed and accessing shared mail folders on a Cyrus IMAP server with Evolution now functions as intended. (BZ#1098036) Due to an incorrectly saved location, an attempt to add a new "Weather" calendar could cause the Evolution client to terminate unexpectedly. The underlying source code has been modified to fix this bug, and Evolution no longer crashes in the described scenario. (BZ#1122644) An LDAP address book search could cause the "evolution-addressbook-factory" process to terminate unexpectedly. This bug has been fixed and the evolution-addressbook-factory process no longer crashes in the described situation. (BZ#1131927) In certain situations, a connection to a Google Calendar could fail due to new restrictions on the Google server. Evolution Data Server has been modified to cope with the new restrictions, and the connection no longer fails. (BZ#1141691) The Evolution client could not connect to a mail server using the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) connection when the server had SSL disabled due to the POODLE vulnerability. With this update, the Evolution Data Server has been modified to connect also using the Transport Layer Security (TLSv1) connection to address this bug. (BZ#1153723) Due to a bug in the related Camel code, which caused use-after-free memory problems, Evolution could terminate unexpectedly under certain circumstances. A patch has been provided to fix this bug, and Evolution no longer crashes. (BZ#1170552) In addition, this update adds the following enhancement: This update introduces the support for multiple connections during IMAP operations into the IMAPX library. Now, IMAPX is significantly more responsive during demanding IMAP operations, such as folder updates. (BZ#1083601) Users of evolution-data-server are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add this enhancement. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
